title: Gleason Archer Jr.
text:
Gleason Leonard Archer Jr. (May 22, 1916 – April 27, 2004) was a <a href="Bible">biblical</a> scholar, theologian, <a href="education">educator</a> and author.
Early life.
Gleason Archer was born in <a href="Norwell%2C%20Massachusetts">Norwell, Massachusetts</a> in 1916 and became a Christian at a young age through the influence of his mother, Elizabeth Archer. His maternal grandfather was a pastor. Archer's father was <a href="Gleason%20Archer%20Sr.">Gleason Archer Sr.</a>, the founder of <a href="Suffolk%20Law%20School">Suffolk Law School</a> in Boston. Archer grew up in Boston and spent summers in Norwell. He graduated from <a href="Boston%20Latin%20School">Boston Latin School</a> and in 1938 he graduated from <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> with a BA (<a href="summa%20cum%20laude">summa cum laude</a> in <a href="Classics">Classics</a>). He received an <a href="LL.B.">LL.B.</a> from <a href="Suffolk%20University">Suffolk Law School</a> in Boston in 1939, the same year he was admitted to the <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a> <a href="bar%20%28law%29">bar</a>. In 1940 he received a master's degree from Harvard and in 1944 he was awarded a PhD at Harvard University in Classics. Finally he received his <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Divinity">Bachelor of Divinity</a> from <a href="Princeton%20Theological%20Seminary">Princeton Theological Seminary</a> in 1945.
Career.
Archer served as an assistant pastor of <a href="Park%20Street%20Church">Park Street Church</a> in Boston from 1945 to 1948. He then became a Professor of Biblical Languages at <a href="Fuller%20Theological%20Seminary">Fuller Theological Seminary</a> in <a href="Pasadena%2C%20California">Pasadena, California</a> from 1948 to 1965. From 1965 to 1986 he served as a Professor of <a href="Old%20Testament">Old Testament</a> and <a href="Semitic%20languages">Semitics</a> at <a href="Trinity%20Evangelical%20Divinity%20School">Trinity Evangelical Divinity School</a>, <a href="Deerfield%2C%20Illinois">Deerfield, Illinois</a>. He became an <a href="emeritus">emeritus</a> faculty member in 1989. The remainder of his life was spent researching, writing, and lecturing.
Archer served as one of the 50 original translators of the <a href="New%20American%20Standard%20Bible">NASB</a> published in 1971. He also worked on the team which translated the <a href="New%20International%20Version">NIV</a> Bible published in 1978. His defense of the doctrine of <a href="Biblical%20inerrancy">Biblical inerrancy</a> by proposing harmonizations and <a href="exegesis">exegesis</a> regarding <a href="inconsistencies%20in%20the%20Bible">inconsistencies in the Bible</a> made Archer a well known <a href="Biblical%20inerrancy">biblical inerrantist</a>. He stated: "One cannot allow for error in history-science without also ending up with error in doctrine." He was critical of the documentary hypothesis which denies the <a href="Mosaic%20authorship">Mosaic authorship</a> of the <a href="Torah">Pentateuch</a>. Archer also maintained that the prophet <a href="Isaiah">Isaiah</a> wrote the entire <a href="book%20of%20Isaiah">book of Isaiah</a>; he wrote regarding this issue: "There is not a shred of internal evidence to support the theory of a Second Isaiah, apart from a philosophical prejudice against the possibility of predictive prophecy."
